Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: An external auditor has just requested specific financial statements for an immediate review.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means so much to your grandmother.” My heart squeezed with the weight of her words. Being the eldest daughter, I knew how important it was to uphold our family’s traditions, especially now, when everyone looked to me to keep them alive. But as I glanced at my laptop, the email from the external auditor blinked insistently. They needed the quarterly financial statements by the end of the day—no exceptions, no delays. My manager had stressed the importance of accuracy and timeliness, especially with the company’s reputation on the line. I felt torn, pulled between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my profession. The pressure built in my chest as I imagined my grandmother’s hopeful eyes and my manager’s stern voice. I sat frozen, the weight of both worlds pressing down, unsure which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
